anbn.description:
Suppose we have $G = (\{S\}, \{a,b\}, S, P)$ with production rules:
$S \rightarrow aSb\ |\ ab$
anbn.question: What is the language $L(G)$ for this grammar?
correctFeedback: Wow! That is an amazingly simple grammar!

anbnreg.description:
Suppose we have $G = (\{S\}, \{a,b\}, S, P)$ with production rules:
$S \rightarrow aSb\ |\ ab$
anbnreg.question: Is the language $L(G)$ regular?

grammartype.description:
Suppose we have $G = (\{S\}, \{a,b\}, S, P)$ with production rules:
$S \rightarrow aSb\ |\ ab$
grammartype.question: What type of grammar is this?
correctFeedback: A grammar is linear if it is context free and has at most a single variable on the RHS of any production rule.
incorrectFeedback: Remember that to be regular, a grammar has to be left linear or right linear. But a grammar is linear if it is context free and has at most a single variable on the RHS of any production rule.

derivation.description:
Suppose we have $G = (\{S\}, \{a,b\}, S, P)$ with production rules:
$S \rightarrow aSb\ |\ ab$

Here is a derivation for $aaabbb$:
$S \Rightarrow aSb \Rightarrow aaSbb \Rightarrow aaabbb$
derivation.question: What do we mean by the derivation of string $aaabbb$?
derivation.answer: Begin with the start variable of the grammar and do replacements until we reach the string $aaabbb$.
choices: Begin with the start variable of the grammar and do replacements until we reach the string $aaabbb$.

sentential.description:
Suppose we have $G = (\{S\}, \{a,b\}, S, P)$ with production rules:
$S \rightarrow aSb\ |\ ab$

Here is a derivation for $aaabbb$:
$S \Rightarrow aSb \Rightarrow aaSbb \Rightarrow aaabbb$

Every step in the derivation process yields what is called a Sentential form. A Sentential form is just a string of variables and terminals that can be derived from the start variable.
sentential.question: Based on the derivation of the sting $aaabbb$, select all sentential forms.

palen.description:
Suppose $G = (\{S\}, \Sigma, S, P)$
$\Sigma = \{a,b\}$
$P = \{S \rightarrow aSa\ |\ bSb\ |\ a\ |\ b\ |\ \lambda\}$
palen.question: What is the langauge $L(G)$ for this grammar?
correctFeedback: This is the palindrones on alphabet $\{a, b\}$.

palenreg.description:
Suppose $G = (\{S\}, \Sigma, S, P)$
$\Sigma = \{a,b\}$
$P = \{S \rightarrow aSa\ |\ bSb\ |\ a\ |\ b\ |\ \lambda\}$
palenreg.question: Is this a regular language?
palenreg.answer: No, we proved that using Pumping Lemma
choices: No, we proved that using Pumping Lemma

palentype.description:
Suppose $G = (\{S\}, \Sigma, S, P)$
$\Sigma = \{a,b\}$
$P = \{S \rightarrow aSa\ |\ bSb\ |\ a\ |\ b\ |\ \lambda\}$
palentype.question: What is the type of this grammar?

palenex.description:
Suppose $G = (\{S\}, \Sigma, S, P)$
$\Sigma = \{a,b\}$
$P = \{S \rightarrow aSa\ |\ bSb\ |\ a\ |\ b\ |\ \lambda\}$
palenex.question: Is the string $ababa$ in $L(G)$?

palender1.description:
Suppose $G = (\{S\}, \Sigma, S, P)$
$\Sigma = \{a,b\}$
$P = \{S \rightarrow aSa\ |\ bSb\ |\ a\ |\ b\ |\ \lambda\}$
palender1.question: Let us derive the sting $ababa$. Which production should we use first?

palensent1.description:
Suppose $G = (\{S\}, \Sigma, S, P)$
$\Sigma = \{a,b\}$
$P = \{S \rightarrow aSa\ |\ bSb\ |\ a\ |\ b\ |\ \lambda\}$
palensent1.question: Substituting $S$ with $aSa$ will give which sentential form?

palender2.description:
Suppose $G = (\{S\}, \Sigma, S, P)$
$\Sigma = \{a,b\}$
$P = \{S \rightarrow aSa\ |\ bSb\ |\ a\ |\ b\ |\ \lambda\}$
palender2.question: Currently we have $S\Rightarrow aSa$. What is the next production rule we will use to derive the string $ababa$?

palensent2.description:
Suppose $G = (\{S\}, \Sigma, S, P)$
$\Sigma = \{a,b\}$
$P = \{S \rightarrow aSa\ |\ bSb\ |\ a\ |\ b\ |\ \lambda\}$
palensent2.question: Currently we have $S\Rightarrow aSa \Rightarrow $ ?. Select the new sentential form that we will get after substituting $S$ with $bSb$

palender3.description:
Suppose $G = (\{S\}, \Sigma, S, P)$
$\Sigma = \{a,b\}$
$P = \{S \rightarrow aSa\ |\ bSb\ |\ a\ |\ b\ |\ \lambda\}$
palender3.question: Currently we have $S\Rightarrow aSa \Rightarrow abSba$. What is the next production rule we will use to derive the string $ababa$?

palensent3.description:
Suppose $G = (\{S\}, \Sigma, S, P)$
$\Sigma = \{a,b\}$
$P = \{S \rightarrow aSa\ |\ bSb\ |\ a\ |\ b\ |\ \lambda\}$

Derivation of $ababa$:
$S \Rightarrow aSA \Rightarrow abSba \Rightarrow ababa$
palensent3.question: Currently we have $S\Rightarrow aSa \Rightarrow abSba \Rightarrow$. Select the new sentential form that we will get after substituting $S$ with $b$

multiex.description:
Consider the grammar $G$ =($\{S,A,B\}$,$\{a,b,c\}$,S,P)
$S\rightarrow AcB$
$A\rightarrow aAa$ | $\lambda$
$B\rightarrow Bbb$ | $\lambda$
multiex.question: What is the type for this grammar?
multiex.answer: Context-Free Grammar (but it happens to be a Regular Language)
choices: Context-Free Grammar (but it happens to be a Regular Language)
Context-Free Grammar for a non-regular language

aacbbder1.question: Let us derive $aacbb$. What variable do we start with?

aacbbsent1.question: What will be the sentential form after we substitute $S$?

aacbborder.question: Since we have a sentential form with multiple variables, which variable should be replaced?
aacbborder.answer: We will need some order to be able to write an algorithm to perform replacements.
choices: We will need some order to be able to write an algorithm to perform replacements.
correctFeedback: We have two variables to choose from, so two possible orders to perform replacements.

aacbbleft.description:
$G$ =($\{S,A,B\}$,$\{a,b,c\}$,S,P)
$S\rightarrow AcB$
$A\rightarrow aAa$ | $\lambda$
$B\rightarrow Bbb$ | $\lambda$
$\textbf {Definition}$: Leftmost derivation: in each step of a derivation, replace the leftmost variable.
aacbbleft.question: Currently, we have $S \Rightarrow AcB$. Following the Leftmost derivation order, which variable should be replaced?
aacbbleft.answer: A as it is the leftmost variable
choices: A as it is the leftmost variable
B as it is the rightmost variable

aacbbder2.description:
$G$ =($\{S,A,B\}$,$\{a,b,c\}$,S,P)
$S\rightarrow AcB$
$A\rightarrow aAa$ | $\lambda$
$B\rightarrow Bbb$ | $\lambda$
$\textbf {Definition}$: Leftmost derivation: in each step of a derivation, replace the leftmost variable.
aacbbder2.question: Currently, we have $S \Rightarrow \underline{A}cB$. Following the Leftmost derivation order, which production should we use to replace $A$?

aacbbsent2.description:
$G$ =($\{S,A,B\}$,$\{a,b,c\}$,S,P)
$S\rightarrow AcB$
$A\rightarrow aAa$ | $\lambda$
$B\rightarrow Bbb$ | $\lambda$
$\textbf {Definition}$: Leftmost derivation: in each step of a derivation, replace the leftmost variable.
aacbbsent2.question: Currently, we have $S \Rightarrow \underline{A}cB$. What will be the sentential form after we substitute $A$ with $aAa$

$S\rightarrow AcB$
$A\rightarrow aAa$ | $\lambda$
$B\rightarrow Bbb$ | $\lambda$

aacbbvar3.question: Currently, we have $S \Rightarrow \underline{A}cB \Rightarrow aAacB$. Following the Leftmost derivation order, which variable should be replaced?
aacbbvar3.answer: A as it is the leftmost variable
choices: A as it is the leftmost variable
B as it is the rightmost variable

$B\rightarrow Bbb$ | $\lambda$

aacbbsent3.question: Currently, we have $S \Rightarrow \underline{A}cB \Rightarrow a\underline{A}acB$. What will be the sentential form after we substitute $A$ with $\lambda$?

aacbbvar4.description:
$G$ =($\{S,A,B\}$,$\{a,b,c\}$,S,P)
$S\rightarrow AcB$
$A\rightarrow aAa$ | $\lambda$
$B\rightarrow Bbb$ | $\lambda$
$\textbf {Definition}$: Leftmost derivation: in each step of a derivation, replace the leftmost variable.
aacbbvar4.question: Currently, we have $S \Rightarrow \underline{A}cB \Rightarrow a\underline{A}acB \Rightarrow aacB$. Following the Leftmost derivation order, which variable should be replaced?
aacbbvar4.answer: B as it is the only variable we have
choices: We are finished as there are no leftmost variables
B as it is the only variable we have
